title: Places
name: Places
description:
A Map by Oleander

Places that I am drawn to because I've been there or  want to go there

properties.name: Anchor Town - The Iceberg
properties.description: Posted by PlacekraftAnchorage, AK

properties.name: Boundary Waters
properties.description: Posted by Oleander Boundary Waters of MinnesotaMany years (decades now) I spent the better part of a summer here. I was working with a group of volunteers building trails and bridges and the like. We lived on an island and traveled by canoe. Our only contact with the outside world was a walkie talkie and our only way off the island was a park service boat. There were rough spots, granted, but I will never get over living in a tent surrounded by bear, moose, eagles, and gods only know what else. The distance of time have turned the place into a land of mysticsm. I honestly wish I could do that kind of camping again.

properties.name: Brazil
properties.description: Posted by OleanderbrazilI\'ve never been to Brazil and I\'m not real sure which area, specifically, I would like to go - I just know that I\'d like to travel there. I\'ve heard they have an entirely sustainable eco-friendly community developed there (though I don\'t know where) and there was an open-source conference/festival (read: geeks with lots of equipment, open source software, and demonstrations of what they\'ve done with it...followed by discourse on the politcs of open source). From what little I know, I am impressed by both the envrinmental attitude and the technological libralism. Of course, there\'s also the natural landscape. frankly, outside of the two things listed already, I know practically nothing about this country - to my mind it\'s a lush green forest with lots of rain and giant flat leaves with water dropping off of them and into lakes or hollowed out trees. But, that\'s one of the reasons why I love to travel - to find out the reality of the world and replace my fragmented assumptions with lived experience.

properties.name: Chequamegon National Forest
properties.description: Posted by Oleander Medford WISomewhere in this forest (located near the town of Medford) is a little campground with a lake and a full moon that the wolves howl to at night. The campground consists of dirt spots for tents and parking spaces for those who drive instead of hike and fire rings. Not much else - and you drop payment into a bax. Someday I\'ll go back.

properties.name: Devil's Tower National Monument
properties.description: Posted by OleanderDevils Tower, WY 82714There is something about this place that keeps drawing me to it every time I travel through the region. It\'s pretty touristy and more crowded than I would prefer but hiking the trail around the perimeter, carefully navigating from one enormous rock to another until I can practically touch the base of the tower, and feeling the sun (or the rain) set in brilliant reds (that I swear are specific to this one spot in the entire world) is all that I can think about when i find myself within driving distance.

properties.name: Hawk Mountain
properties.description: Posted by Oleander Hawk MountainThe oldest sanctuary and rehabilitation center for birds of prey in the USA. There\'s a long list of birds that come through hawk Mountain each year as they migrate from one place to another and I like birds - who doesn\'t? This is also a campground with hiking trails and heaven only knows what else. Camping on the mountain where migratory birds like Hawks and Eagles have a safe wayside along their long annual journey doesn\'t have a mystic appeal, per se...something equally as strong but more earthy. It\'s a place to connect with others traveling along their routes home - wherever home may be during this half of the year. I\'ve been hoping to get there for about 5 years now but it just hasn\'t worked out for one reason or another.

properties.name: High Resolution Mass Spectrometry Group
properties.description: Posted by KkmurrayKraków, PolandThe group unites scientists of the Regional Laboratory and the Faculty of Chemistry, Jagiellonian University.

properties.name: Olympic National Park
properties.description: Posted by Oleander    Glacier capped mountains, wild Pacific coast and magnificent stands of old-growth forests, including temperate rain forests -- at Olympic National Park, you can find all three. About 95% of the park is designated wilderness, which further protects these diverse and spectacular ecosystems.

properties.name: Parc national de la Gaspésie, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts, Québec, Canada
properties.description: Posted by Oleander    Sainte-Anne-des-Monts, Québec, CanadaI am told that one branch of my family stretches out into Quebec Canada. I\'ve had this little thought, way in the back of my mind, that I might go there someday - just to the see the place. But, I long since decided that I\'d rather see the country than the specific farm distant ancestors lived and worked on. I want to see Quebec in the quiet of it\'s natural places. Hardly anything can be called untouched anymore, but the national parks and nature preserves have more to say about the land named for any country you care to mention than the city streets or the guide books. The cities will pass along the nature of the feet that have passed there, but the dirt and trees will tell you about the land itself. http://www.sentier.ca/index.php?lang=en&section_id=1 http://www.sepaq.com/pq/fr/

properties.name: Park on the Ocean's Edge in Seattle WA
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderseattle waI lived here for a while. Honestly, I think its the most beautiful (USA) city I\'ve ever been to and almost the cleanest (worldwide). Besides, I love the ocean and I did not take advantage of my proximity to it anywhere near enough. I would like to find this park (again), and sit on the oceans edge for a while. Then, perhaps, I could jump on a ferry to visit the islands, a boat to see the whales, and a ship to travel onward to Alaska. Maybe...

properties.name: Petroglyphs
properties.description: Posted by Oleandermoab UtahIn this approximate area I saw a sign for Petroglyphs at the next exit. I pulled off at the first wayside, which had it\'s own pet raven and the last outdoor waterpumps on the road headed west. The Petroglyphs were at the end of a long country road that wound through public land. I camped there alone under a full moon and in between fast and short rainstorms.

properties.name: Soooo cold.....
properties.description: Posted by Epratt76reykjavik icelandCold, windy, snowy, crayons and almost falling off ponies... That\'s what I remember about Iceland as a child.

properties.name: St. Stephen's Cathedral
properties.description: Posted by Oleandervienna, austriaI think this is the right location for the Cathedral, but I\'m not sure because every attempt to enter in the address returned a \'not found\' error. Sometimes it\'s hard to know whether to search in the language of the location or in my own language. Regardless, this is one of those places that I\'ve been to and have rather powerful memories of. All i did ws walk into the Cathedral (2 or 3 times, at the most) and wander around while a man playeed songs I no longer remember on a giant pipe organ. There is something very powerful about the cathedral. It was as though i could sense the presence of every footstep that had passed there. Not in an I-see-ghosts kinda way, but in a this-place-has-the-energy-of-many-worshipers-seeped-into-it\'s-stones manner. The one thing I remember most vividly was a railing on a spiral staircase that was closed to general traffic. The railing consisted of (what felt like) stone that had been carved into a long series of frogs eating one another. The mouth of one was clamped onto the backside of another, and they lay that way from the first step all the way up as far as i could see. The frogs at the very bottom were worn down to the point of almost losing their frog-resemblance. As i touched these fading amphibian railing residents i realized that they had been filed away by the touch of hands that had brushed accross them over centuries of time. While the first step accross the threshold told me this place had a strong power to it, the touch of the frogs was the point where I realized why.

properties.name: The Square and the Bridge in Prague
properties.description: Posted by Oleanderprague czech republicThere\'s a bridge that I walked along, admiring the bas-relief (sp?) images all along the wall, when I came across children reaching up to touch one of the images. They were so intent on putting their fingers on a specific spot that one child lifted another just enough to reach the image (because neither to get to it on their own). When they scampered off I took a closer look. The spot they touched was worn shiny and smooth from the touch of fingers over the years. I reached up and touched it myself without knowing exactly why it was important but being well aware of the truth about children - if it\'s a lucky charm, they\'ll know where it is.

properties.name: The Tiny Waterfall
properties.description: Posted by OleanderDubuque IowaSomewhere in this region there is a state park with the tiniest waterfal I have ever seen. It flows into a round pool of dark bluegreen water and simply hums with the energy of fairy folk.
